> I don't know if there's a reason for it, but what I've done is created a
> subclass of TestCase and implemented lots more assert methods, like
> assertArrayEquals, assertContains, assertEndsWith, assertNotContains,
> assertNotEmpty, etc. They are quite simple to write and they make the test
> code a lot cleaner.

Maybe writing all these assert methods was quicker than downloading JUnit-addons
and add it to your classpath.

ArrayAssert.equals, StringAssert.assertEndsWith, StringAssert.assertNotContains
are some of the methods featured in JUnit-addons.  And if you have written
additional ones, feel free to send a patch.

-Vladimir
